concepts.title: System Design Interview Mindset
concepts.summary: Treat the interview as a collaboration simulation: clarify, communicate, and show trade-offs rather than aiming for a perfect final design.

sections.name: What Interviewers Look For
points: Collaboration style, handling ambiguity, and ability to ask clarifying questions.
How you defend choices, respond to feedback, and manage time under pressure.
Avoid red flags: overengineering, narrow-mindedness, and silent problem solving.

sections.name: Four-Step Framework
points: Step 1: Understand & scope — clarify features, scale (DAU), growth, environment; write assumptions.
Step 2: High-level design — sketch components (clients, LB, web, DB/cache/CDN, MQ) and get buy-in.
Step 3: Deep dive — focus on hardest parts and bottlenecks; avoid low-value rabbit holes.
Step 4: Wrap-up — recap choices, call out bottlenecks/risks, monitoring, rollout, and next-scale changes.

sections.name: Clarifying Questions
points: Features: read-only vs read/write; platform (web, mobile, both).
Scale: DAU, friend count/limits, request volumes, content types.
Growth: speed to 10M/100M users; expected traffic ramp.
Environment: existing infra (cache, CDN, queue, DB) you can leverage.

sections.name: News Feed Example
points: Agree on scope: mobile/web, reverse chronological, content types (text/images/video), friend max, DAU.
Fanout on write for typical users: push post IDs to each friend’s feed cache.
Hybrid for celebrities: fanout on read (merge from celeb cache) to avoid massive write storms.
Fast reads: personal feed cache + efficient batch fetch of post/user/media details.

sections.name: Pitfalls & Trade-offs
points: Overengineering vs practical constraints (cost/time).
Ignoring bottlenecks like fanout for heavy hitters or aggregation latency on read.
Failing to state assumptions or consider environment re-use.

sections.name: Time Allocation (45 min)
points: Step 1: 3–10 min; Step 2: 10–15 min; Step 3: 10–25 min; Step 4: 3–5 min.
Stay high-level first, then dive deep on critical components.

sections.name: Cost-Aware Thought
points: Be ready to drop non-essential components (e.g., CDN layer) for cost, accepting moderate latency.
Articulate why that trade-off is acceptable for an early-stage startup.

sections.name: Dos and Don’ts
points: Do: ask clarifying questions, talk through thinking, offer alternatives, collaborate.
Don’t: skip requirements, dive too deep too early, assume perfection or declare “done” prematurely.
